snippet.title: React Error Boundaries with Typescript in Hindi
snippet.description:
#react #typescript #hindi #react-hooks #react-router #useEffect #useState #custom  Hooks #useRef #useReducer #project #react-query #lodash #react-bootstrap #errorboundaries
React Error Boundaries with Typescript in Hindi

React Error boundaries concept with an example. 
Please watch the video and provide feedback.

Time Stamp :-

Introduction - 00:00
KeyPoints - 00:27
Practical project start: 4:47

Videos:
Project Part -1: https://youtu.be/-tNMukn-3oU
Project Part-2: https://youtu.be/23V8Q6875RU
useReducer hook:  https://youtu.be/zIAHXQ7wi6c
useContext + useReducer hook: https://youtu.be/B5oDD66v688

Project: https://github.com/anujsingla/react-typescript-project
React tutorial: https://github.com/anujsingla/react-course
React router dom - https://reactrouter.com/web/guides/quick-start
Error Boundaries: https://reactjs.org/docs/error-boundaries.html

Key Points:

Error Boundaries
- In the past, javascript errors inside react components were not handled and it breaks
  the UI, React did not provide a way to handle these errors.
- React 16 introduces a new concept of an “error boundary”.
- It catches javascript errors anywhere in their child components tree, logs those errors displays a fallback UI.

Error boundaries do not catch errors for:
- Event handlers (learn more)
- Asynchronous code (e.g. setTimeout or requestAnimationFrame callbacks)
- Server-side rendering
- Errors are thrown in the error boundary itself (rather than its children)
Twitter: https://twitter.com/singla387

snippet.title: Learn React Redux Typescript from Scratch with a project in Hindi | Part - 1
snippet.description:
#react #typescript #hindi #react-hooks #react-router #useEffect #useState #custom  Hooks #useRef #useReducer #project #react-query #lodash #react-bootstrap #errorboundaries #multiform

Learn React Redux Typescript from Scratch with a project in Hindi | Part - 1

Please watch the video and provide feedback.

Time Stamp:-

Introduction - 00:00
Redux Three principles: 1:07
Build Project: 7:27
Create redux store: 8:37
Create redux reducer: 18:07
Create UI component: 40:47
Redux error state: 51:27

key points:
Redux
   - State management library for the javascript application
   - we can use it with React, angular, vue, or other javascript framework or library
   - A single centralized place to contain the global state and impose 
     certain restrictions on how and when updates can happen.

Redux three principles
- Single source of truth
    - Application has a single store.
    - Easier to debug.

- State is read-only
    - We can only change the state with action and reducer.
    - State can not be changed by view or any network call.

- Changes are made with pure functions
    - Reducers are pure functions that take the previous state and and
    action and return to the next state.

snippet.title: React Redux RTK Query with Typescript from Scratch with a project in Hindi | Part - 1
snippet.description:
React Redux RTK Query with Typescript from Scratch with a project in Hindi | Part - 1
#react #redux #toolkit #rtkquery

RTK Query

- It is used to fetch, mutate and cache the data.
- It is the same as React Query.
- It is an optional add-on included in the redux toolkit package.
- It provides various features like fetching the data, mutations,
re-fetching, cache, conditional fetching, error handling, polling.
- We will check with an example

Github link for the project: https://github.com/anujsingla/redux-rtk
RTK Query documentation: https://redux-toolkit.js.org/rtk-query/overview

Support my channel:
https://www.buymeacoffee.com/anujsingla

snippet.title: What is React Fragements |  React Fragment in React JS (Hindi) | React Tutorial with Typescript
snippet.description:
What is React Fragments |  React Fragment in React JS (Hindi) | React Tutorial with Typescript

React Fragments helps to render multiple elements without wrapping them in an extra DOM node. It will not produce any extra elements in the DOM.

⏰ Timecodes ⏰
0:00 Introduction
0:27 What is React Fragment?
4:07 React Fragment with example
10:27 React Fragment with array of elements
13:27 Conclusion

Key points:

Before fragment, If we want to render multiple elements in the React
then we need to wrap under one DOM node.
After fragment (16.2.0 React release), We can render multiple elements
without wrapping them in an extra DOM node. It will not produce any extra
elements in the DOM. It enables us to group multiple components without
introducing any unnecessary markup in the rendered HTML.
We should use this when we need it.
As per documentation, Fragment only accepts key attributes.

Benefit:
- It will help to avoid extra DOM elements in the UI.
- It avoids issues that break layouts like Flexbox or CSS Grid have special parent-child relationships and adding extra divs in the middle
makes it hard to keep the desired layout.

snippet.title: What is React.memo |  React memo in React JS (Hindi) | Mastering React Memo
snippet.description:
What is React.memo |  React memo in React JS (Hindi) | Mastering React Memo

Github project: https://github.com/anujsingla/interview_questions_answer

⏰ Timecodes ⏰
0:00 What is React.memo
8:57 When to use React.memo
11:07 When not to use React.memo
13:17 Understand React.memo with a basic example
21:17 Understand React.memo with a function example
26:17 Understand React.memo with a practical example
31:07 Conclusion

keypoints:

/*
- What is React.memo
- Examples
- When to use React.memo
- When not to use React.memo


To improve user interface performance, React offers a high-order
component "React.memo()". We need to wrap a component, React memorizes the
rendered output of the wrapped component and skips unnecessary renderings.

While updating DOM, React first render the component and compare the result with
the previous render. If the render results are different, React Updates the
DOM. Comparison between previous and new render components is very fast. But
we can speed up the process.

When we wrapped our component in the "React.memo()" component, React renders
the component and memoizes the result.
While updating DOM, If component props don't change then React reuses the
memoized result and skipping the next rendering.
If component props change then React render the component and memoizes the
latest component.

React.memo only check for prop changes. It will not check for state updates,
useReducer or useContext. It will still re-render when the state or context change.

By Default, It will only shallow compare complex objects in the props object.
If you want to control over the comparsion, you can provide a custom comparison
function as a second argument.
It is only used for performance Optimization.

React.memo used for function component.
React.PureComponent used for class component.

Without custom comparison function:

const MyComponent = React.memo(function MyComponent(props) {
  component logic
});

With custom comparison function:

function MyComponent(props) {}
function areEqual(prevProps, nextProps) {}
export default React.memo(MyComponent, areEqual);

When to use React.memo:
- Pure functional component
- Component should render with the same props or minor props changes
- Renders frequently
- Medium or large component contains a decent amount of UI
elements to reason props equality check.

When not to use React.memo:

- React.memo explicitly cache the component which means it stores the result
(VDOM) in memory. If we do this too many or big components this leads to
more memory consumption. You should be careful while memoizing large component.

- Do not use React.memo if component props change frequently. It creates 
additional overhead which compares the props with the memoized one. It will
not affect performance too much but you miss the final goal of React.memo is made
for.

- Don't use memoization if you can't quantify the performance gains.

Example with different scenarios:
Basic React.memo scenarios
Dealing with objects.
Dealing with functions.

*/

------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

snippet.title: How React compare useEffect dependency array object (previous object and new object) | useEffect
snippet.description:
How React compare useEffect dependency array object (previous object and new object)

Github repo for question and answers: https://github.com/anujsingla/interview_questions_answer

⏰ Timecodes ⏰
0:00 Introduction
0:37 What is useEffect hook?
1:17 How React compare useEffect dependency array object
3:27 Practical Example
18:47 Conclusion

/*
Key points:

useEffect dependency array object comparison

useEffect accepts two arguments.
1- Callback function
2 - Dependency array

useEffect(() = {
  logic
}, [values]);

The dependency array tells the hook to only trigger when the dependency array
changes. It means run the callback function when the value changes in the
dependency array.

React uses "Object.is()" to compare dependencies array. React do
a comparison between each of the values to determine whether effect callback
should be called.
If you we provide an new object on every render, even if none of the
properties changed, effect callback called every time like props as an object.

- Example

*/

snippet.title: React 18 new features with Typescript and examples | React 18 - Everything you need to know
snippet.description:
React 18 new features with Typescript and examples | React 18 - Everything you need to know

#react #react18 #typescript #hindi

Please watch the video and provide feedback.

Videos:
Project Part -1: https://youtu.be/-tNMukn-3oU
Project Part-2: https://youtu.be/23V8Q6875RU
useReducer hook:  https://youtu.be/zIAHXQ7wi6c
useContext + useReducer hook: https://youtu.be/B5oDD66v688

Project:
Project: https://github.com/anujsingla/react-typescript-project
React tutorial: https://github.com/anujsingla/react-course
React 18 - https://github.com/anujsingla/react18

Topic:
React router dom - https://reactrouter.com/web/guides/quick-start
Error Boundaries: https://reactjs.org/docs/error-boundaries.html
React 18 - https://github.com/reactwg/react-18/discussions
React 18 plan - https://reactjs.org/blog/2021/06/08/the-plan-for-react-18.html

Key Points:

React 18:

It comes full of new features, will improve the performance and loading of every app.

- Replacing ReactDOM.render with ReactDOM.createRoot
- Automatic batching: 
    - Batching is when React groups multiple state updates into a single re-render for better performance.
- Handling Slow Updates with startTransition API.
    - It tells React which updates are urgent and which are not urgent

- Suspense:
    - In the 16, 17 version, Basic support for suspense
    - Get full support for Suspense
        - It suspends something until it's ready to be rendered.

Time Stamp :-

Introduction - 00:00
KeyPoints - 1:30
Install react 18 version: 5:17 
ReactDOM.render with ReactDom.Createroot :- 7:07
Automatic batching: 9:17
startTransition API: 16:27
Suspense: 23:37

- Many more features, will cover in the upcoming videos.

snippet.title: useTransition vs useDeferredValue hook | React 18 | What is Concurrent React | Anuj Singla
snippet.description:
useTransition vs useDeferredValue hook | React 18 | What is Concurrent React | Anuj Singla
In this video, I have explained Concurrency, useTransition, and useDeferredValue concepts. React has added these features in 18 versions.

Github project: https://github.com/anujsingla/React18features

useTransition vs useDeferredValue hook | React 18 | What is Concurrent React | Anuj Singla

Topics covered:
React 18 concept
What is Concurrency in React js
What is useTransition Hook
What is useDeferredValue Hook
How is useDefferedValue different from debouncing?
What is the difference between useDefferedValue and useTransition hook?
Practical example

⏰ Timecodes ⏰
0:00 Introduction
0:27 What is Concurrency in React js
6:07 What is useTransition Hook
7:57 What is useDeferredValue Hook
9:37 How is useDefferedValue different from debouncing?
10:27 Difference between useDefferedValue and useTransition hook?
12:27 Practical example
39:07 Conclusion

Concurrency Means:
React 18 added a new concept: Concurrency. Concurrency helps to update multiple tasks
simultaneously by prioritizing the tasks. We can prioritize state updates 
like low priority or high priority state updates.

Explained By Dan Abramov -
https://github.com/reactwg/react-18/discussions/46#discussioncomment-846786
https://react-beta-seven.vercel.app/

useTransition hook:
Transitions are a new concurrent feature introduced in React 18 to distinguish 
between urgent and non-urgent updates.
Urgent updates like typing, clicking, pressing, etc.
Non-urgent updates like UI updates on some state updates.
Example: You filter the product list on search. Typing in the input box to search
product is an urgent state update and shows the filtered product in a non-urgent state.
React added this feature to improve the User experience.

React added hook for this:
const [isPending, startTransition] = useTransition();
isPending - state for pending transition.
startTransition - function to start the transition.

startTransition(() = {
  setCount(count + 1);
})

https://reactjs.org/docs/react-api.html#transitions
https://github.com/reactwg/react-18/discussions/46#discussioncomment-846786
https://reactjs.org/blog/2022/03/29/react-v18.html?#new-feature-transitions
https://academind.com/tutorials/react-usetransition-vs-usedeferredvalue
https://dmitripavlutin.com/react-usetransition/

useDeferredValue() hook

useTransition() hook gives us the control to make the state a low priority.
useDeferredValue lets you defer (postpone) re-rendering a non-urgent part
of the tree.
It is the same as debouncing. There is no fixed time delay. React will render the
deferred value as soon as other work is finished (the first render is reflected on the
screen). It does not block user input.

How is useDefferedValue different from debouncing?

Debouncing has a fixed artificial delay, no matter other system is fast
or slow. useDeferredValue add lags as per system. On a fast machine, the lag
is less and on a slow device is a high lag and noticeable.

What is the difference between useDefferedValue and useTransition hook?

useTransition hook wrap the updating state and useDefferedValue wrap a value
that is affected by state updates.
We should not use both hooks at the same time because both provide the solution
for the same problem.
Don't overuse this feature for all state updates. We should only use
where we need like complex user interface.
We should keep other performance improvements like lazy loading,
pagination or other performance optimization techniques.

https://reactjs.org/blog/2022/03/29/react-v18.html?#usedeferredvalue
https://github.com/reactwg/react-18/discussions/46#discussioncomment-846786

snippet.title: What is Strict Mode in React Js | Strict Mode in React JS | Strict.Mode in React | Hindi
snippet.description:
It is a helper component that allows developers to code efficiently
and show an error or warning in the console if react guideline and recommendations are not followed in the app. It does not render anything in the UI.

⏰ Timecodes ⏰
0:00 Introduction

Key points:

Strict Mode:
React.StrictMode{child component} /React.StrictMode

It is a helper component that allows developers to code efficiently
and show an error or warning in the console if react guideline and recommendation
not followed in the app.
It does not render anything in the UI.
It is a React developer tool used for highlighting possible problems 
in the application.
We can apply strict mode to any section of the app but recommend to
apply in the root.
Create react app by default and add this component in the root.

React.StrictMode
    App /
/React.StrictMode

Note: It checks in the development mode only. It does not impact the
production build.

Strict Mode called some methods twice to detect any problem
in the app and show warning and error messages in the console.
It is run only in development mode.
constructor method
render
setState
getDerivedStateFromProps
useState
useMemo

Advantage:

Identifying unsafe lifecycles
Warning about legacy string ref API usage
Warning about deprecated findDOMNode usage
Detecting unexpected side effects
Detecting legacy context API
Ensuring reusable state

Example

Reference:
https://reactjs.org/docs/strict-mode.html
https://kentcdodds.com/blog/react-strict-mode
